newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia's PUMA to launch US$700m Eurobond.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia's PUMA to launch US$700m Eurobond.

text.p: PUMA Managament Ltd, Australia's largest private sector mortgage-backed bond issuer, said on Friday it will launch US$700 million worth of Eurobonds in London on March 17.
PUMA said the issue signals the start of its offshore funding programme, part of a A$3 billion total programme for calendar 1997.
The floating rate note issue will be split into three tranches and will be priced at a weighted average margin over time (WAMOT) over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR).

The issue, to be known as E-1 Series 1, will be rated AAA by Standard & Poor's Corp (S&P) and Aaa by Moody's Investors Service for tranches A-1 and A-2, with face values of $105 million and US$560 million respectively.
Tranche B-1, which will be subordinated debt, will be rated AA-minus by S&P and will have a face value of $35 million, PUMA said.

PUMA said it was able to achieve a rating better than Australia's sovereign debt rating of AA and Aa2 by S&P and Moody's respectively because of the structure of the issue which includes a fully pre-payable cross currency swap.
Lead manager is JP Morgan with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell co-lead manager. Co-managers are UBS and SBC Warburg.
Funds raised will be used to fund Australian home loans via mortgage originators, notably PUMA's strategic partner, Aussie Home Loans, the largest non-bank lender in Australia, PUMA said.
